Callables

Emojicode supports a type called callables which is comparable to function types in other programming languages. Callables are objects like any other object and can therefore be stored in variables, passed as argument, etc.

Type

The callable type is declared using this syntax:

callable-type âŸ¶ ğŸ‡ [type-list] [return-type] ğŸ‰
type-list âŸ¶ type | type type-list

Each type stands for one argument of that type. You can specify a returnType. If no return type is specified the callable is assumed to return Nothingness.

Examples:

ğŸ‡ğŸš‚â¡ï¸ğŸ”¡ğŸ‰ ğŸ‘´Takes an integer argument and returns a string
ğŸ‡â¡ï¸ğŸ”£ğŸ‰ ğŸ‘´Takes no arguments and returns a symbol
ğŸ‡ğŸ‰ ğŸ‘´Takes no arguments and returns nothing(ness).

Calling a Callable

The ğŸ­ must be used to call a callable.

callable-call âŸ¶ ğŸ­ expression [arguments]

expression must be a callable. Of course you must provide the required number of correctly typed arguments.

Example of calling a callable:

ğŸ‘´ greet is of type ğŸ‡ğŸ”¡ğŸ‰
ğŸ­ greet ğŸ”¤BobğŸ”¤

Capturing Method Calls

You can capture method calls on instances and types. This creates a callable that takes as many arguments of the same type as the method would take and returns the same value as the method would return. This callable will always execute the method in the same context, though.

The syntax is:

method-capture âŸ¶ ğŸŒ¶ [ğŸ©] method-emoji capturee
capturee âŸ¶ expression | type

method-name is the emoji representing the method. If you want to capture a type method, place the ğŸ© in front of the method name. Iff a type method is to be caputred capturee must be a type.

Example:

ğŸ¦ string ğŸ”¤StrawberryğŸ”¤

ğŸ¦ append ğŸŒ¶ ğŸ“ string

ğŸ˜€ ğŸ­ append ğŸ”Ÿ!
ğŸ˜€ ğŸ­ append ğŸ”Ÿ?

You might have gueesed it, the output of the above is:

Strawberry!
Strawberry?

Closure

You can define closures which remember the environment in which they were defined. The basic syntax to define a closure is:

closure âŸ¶ ğŸ‡ [arguments] [return-type] statements ğŸ‰

This is basically the same syntax that applies to methods and initializers.

Example:

ğŸ¦ greet ğŸ‡ name ğŸ”¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ® out ğŸ”¤ğŸ”¤

  ğŸ”‚ i â© â– ğŸ” name 1 -1 ğŸ‡
    ğŸ® out ğŸ“ out ğŸº ğŸ½ name i
  ğŸ‰

  ğŸ out
ğŸ‰

ğŸ˜€ğŸ­ greet ğŸ”¤FranzğŸ”¤

The above is a very simple example of a closure that simply reverses a given string and will output:

znarF

Letâ€™s take a look at a more advanced use of a closure:

ğŸ‡ğŸ– ğŸ™‹ name ğŸ”¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ‡ğŸš‚â¡ï¸ğŸ”¡ğŸ‰ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ ğŸ‡ hour ğŸš‚ â¡ï¸ ğŸ”¡
    ğŸŠ ğŸ˜› hour 12 ğŸ‡
      ğŸ ğŸª ğŸ”¤Have a good lunch, ğŸ”¤ nameğŸª
    ğŸ‰
    ğŸ ğŸª ğŸ”¤Hello, ğŸ”¤ nameğŸª
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Here weâ€™ve got a class method that returns a closure. The closure actually closes over the name variable here and copies it value so that it can be used when the closure is called later.

Caution

Closures copy the closured local variables and freeze them in the scope of the closure. If you modify one of the copied variable only the copy local to the closure will be modified.

Instance variables are not copied and really change when modified inside a closure.

Now if we call the class method weâ€™ll get a closure:

ğŸ¦ walfriedGreeter ğŸ©ğŸ™‹ğŸ€ ğŸ”¤WalfriedğŸ”¤

Now we can call the closure with an argument for hour:

ğŸ˜€ ğŸ­ walfriedGreeter 7
ğŸ˜€ ğŸ­ walfriedGreeter 12

This will produce:

Hello, Walfried
Have a good lunch, Walfried
